articles.title: Football in sun and without shadow: How extreme heat puts tomorrow‚Äôs stars at risk - Eco-Business
articles.search_term: (heatwave OR "heat wave" OR "severe heatwave" OR "extreme heat" OR "heat spell" OR "scorching heat" OR "blistering heat" OR "sweltering heat" OR "hot winds" OR loo OR "hot loo winds" OR "intense heat" OR "unbearable heat" OR "deadly heat") Andaman and Nicobar Islands
articles.full_text:
It was 33¬∞C when, during a day of trials for Paraguay‚Äôs Cerro Porte√±o youth team, a 16-year-old collapsed. He was one of hundreds who had arrived on 21 November 2025, dreaming of playing for one of the country‚Äôs most popular sports institutions. He suffered a cardiac arrest and had to be saved by the club‚Äôs medical staff.
Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano called football, not only the most popular sport in the world, but ‚Äúthe music of the body, the festival of the eyes‚Äù. It is a beloved hobby of hundreds of thousands of children and teenagers worldwide.
But extreme heat is putting their well-being at risk. Researchers, coaches and scientists are now racing to find solutions, ranging from early warnings and awareness campaigns to banning synthetic pitches that trap heat.
Heat in the home of the world champions
The adult game is also struggling with heat. High temperatures in the United States for the 2024 Copa America forced the South American Football Confederation (Conmebol) to redraw its protocol for medical staff.
A report published last year by Football for Future warned that 14 of the 16 stadiums due to host games at this year‚Äôs men‚Äôs World Cup in Mexico, Canada and the US exceed ‚Äúsafe-play thresholds‚Äù for climate hazards, including extreme heat.
‚Äú
It is not enough to issue general alerts in the media or on social networks in the event of extreme temperatures. This information must be strategically communicated to those who have the trust of others in these communities, such as mothers and coaches.
Gregory Wellenius, researcher, Boston University School of Public Health
But children are known to be more vulnerable to heat than adults. In 2023, all summer youth sports matches in Paraguay were suspended between 10 am and 5 pm due to high temperatures. In Argentina, several local leagues made similar decisions, postponing games due to the heat.
The suspensions in these two countries occurred during a heatwave made 60 times more likely by climate change. One of the places affected was the city of Rosario in Argentina, home to a club where two world champions, Diego Maradona and Lionel Messi, played: Newell‚Äôs Old Boys.
The coordinator of Newell‚Äôs youth divisions, Gustavo Tognarelli, believes the impact of heat ‚Äúis not yet on the agenda in our institutions‚Äù and more clubs need to take it seriously. Tognarelli oversees more than 400 children and adolescents playing for the club and says that the summer heat in Argentina is ‚Äúdifficult‚Äù.
According to the latest Lancet Countdown report, the Latin American region has experienced an increase of hundreds of hours per year, as compared to 1991-2000, during which walking and running pose a health risk.
‚ÄúThe impact is noticeable in training. It‚Äôs not the same for a child who trains at eight in the morning as it is for another who trains at ten,‚Äù Tognarelli told Dialogue Earth.
The recent trend towards synthetic turf pitches has complicated things, he says. They hold up better on rainy days, but ‚Äúgenerate much more heat on the pitch‚Äù.
Iv√°n V√°zquez, director of the youth divisions at Club Olimpia in Paraguay, is even more emphatic: ‚ÄúSynthetic turf pitches should be banned here. The temperatures can hurt the children‚Äôs feet, causing burns when they fall.‚Äù
In addition to training, a constant challenge for youth teams is children having to play on the same day on the same pitch due to infrastructure and transport issues. This can necessitate some children playing during the hottest part of the day, creating problems for complying with guidance on heat exposure put out by health officials and football federations.
Ariel Ram√≠rez, media coordinator for Conmebol, which governs professional football of all ages in South America, says it ‚Äúcontrols high temperatures in its tournaments through strict medical protocols that include monitoring humidity and ambient temperature with specialised equipment‚Äù.
Drinks breaks are mandatory above certain temperatures, along with pre-match medical examinations, acclimatisation and education on heatstroke. This protocol also applies to youth tournaments. It was in force when the 16-year-old collapsed in Paraguay last November. But application can be patchy. A 2018 study warned that ambulances were consistently absent during training sessions and youth matches in Paraguay‚Äôs local leagues.
Children at risk
Conmebol originally developed its protocol for the 2016 Copa Am√©rica in the United States.
Successive football tournaments in the Americas have drawn criticism for their approach to extreme heat. The organisation had to update and broaden its protocol for the 2024 Copa Am√©rica, also in the US, in response to growing evidence on the impact of playing in summer conditions. Despite the new protocol, a referee collapsed in that tournament during one of the nine matches played in dangerously hot conditions.
Gregory Wellenius, a researcher on climate change and environmental health at Boston University School of Public Health, points out that in youth football, the challenge goes beyond having protocols, controlling schedules and playing surfaces.
Cities such as Boston, which will host games at the next World Cup, have protocols and alerts for extreme-heat situations. But these are ‚Äúdesigned for the general population‚Äù and ‚Äúcertainly not children and young footballers‚Äù, he says.
‚ÄúChildren are not small adults; they are thermodynamically different. They sweat differently, and sweating is the mechanism humans have to cool the body,‚Äù Wellenius explains.
Places that historically did not have high temperatures face greater problems in adapting their infrastructure, Wellenius says. ‚ÄúWhat may be common in Houston or Central America is not so common in cities like Boston, which used to be cooler and now experiences heat waves.‚Äù
In addition to physiology and infrastructure, Wellenius believes it is essential to remember that children are also ‚Äúless likely to know when to stop‚Äù when they get too hot in competitive environments.
The full impact of heat on children and adolescents is still unknown. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt really know the long-term impact of exposure to extreme heat on children,‚Äù says the researcher. ‚ÄúWhat happens to their bodies if they are constantly under pressure from high temperatures?‚Äù
Adapting at home ‚Äì and in the stands
Philip Jenkins, one of the lead authors of the Football for Future report on the perils of the coming World Cup, says: ‚ÄúOur analysis shows that by 2050, extreme heat in stadiums will become the new normal, with almost 90 per cent needing to adapt to cope.‚Äù
The report focussed on stadiums hosting this and the next two World Cups as well as grassroots stadiums linked to World Cup legends, such as those where Lionel Messi and Pel√© began their careers. In some of these stadiums, football matches and training will be severely disrupted by extreme temperatures by 2050, for as many as two months per year, the report found.
Faced with this ‚Äúnew normal‚Äù, coaches and researchers say there is no silver-bullet solution.
Cooling breaks and leaving behind synthetic turf pitches in favour of natural grass could help. But more broadly ‚Äúthe region needs to develop early-warning systems for extreme heat‚Äù says Francisco Chesini, a public health researcher at the University of Buenos Aires and part of the Global Heat Health Information Network.
Such systems are already implemented in countries including Spain, where local-level forecasts and temperature thresholds trigger a comprehensive response from authorities and health officials. The United Nations launched an initiative in 2022 for a worldwide adoption of early-warning systems by the end of 2027. Paraguay already aims to develop one as part of its climate policy, pending funding.
‚ÄúThere is still a long way to go to raise awareness of the need to invest in infrastructure,‚Äù says Tognarelli.
But, he adds, ‚ÄúIt is an investment, not an expense. Our role must be to protect and provide comprehensive training for these children.‚Äù
Wellenius says adapting is not about eliminating risks but about empowering people to make informed decisions. There is an untapped opportunity, he says, to use football communities not only to protect children and adolescents in sport, but also to advance understanding and the need for public policies on heat.
‚ÄúPeople know that heat is a problem, but they don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs their problem,‚Äù he says, ‚ÄúIt is not enough to issue general alerts in the media or on social networks in the event of extreme temperatures. This information must be strategically communicated to those who have the trust of others in these communities, such as mothers and coaches.‚Äù
As well as the music of the body and the festival of the eyes, football may also have the power to change minds on climate risks and the need for action.
This article was originally published on Dialogue Earth under a Creative Commons licence.

articles.full_text:
Andhra Pradesh, Telangana Weather LATEST Update: Rain, Heatwave Forecast For Summer Issued
Andhra Pradesh, Telangana Weather LATEST Update: Winter is pretty much over.. summer has begun. The Telangana Weatherman predicts that rains will also pick up during this time. Here's what this summer is expected to be like
Rains are inevitable in summer..
Wondering about rain in summer? It happens, and this year it's starting early. The Telangana Weatherman says Feb, Mar, and Apr will see both sun and rain due to the El Ni√±o effect.
Rains this month...
Half of February is already over... the cold has reduced and the heat has started. According to the Telangana Weatherman, in the coming days, not only will the heat intensify, but rains will also start here and there. He warns that there will be rain for three months... and then the real summer will begin. The Weatherman revealed that May and June will see scorching heat with very high temperatures recorded.
SUMMER 2026 PRELIMINARY FORECAST
EL- NINO IS COMING üî•
The first half of summer which includes Feb 2nd half, March, April will be RAINY and normal summer heat is expected üåßÔ∏è
The second half of summer will be DRIER with MASSIVE HEATWAVES expected during May, June 1st half üî•‚Ä¶‚Äî Telangana Weatherman (@balaji25_t) January 16, 2026
2023 situation in 2026...
The Weatherman warns that 2023's weather patterns will repeat, with a longer summer. The southwest monsoon will be delayed, meaning unavoidable heat and humidity until it arrives.
Cold for another two days...
Currently, the Hyderabad Met Centre says minimum temps may drop 2-3 degrees in the next 2 days, with dry weather continuing. On Feb 12, some districts will see 11-15¬∞C temps.
Lowest temperatures in Telangana are here..
On Feb 11, the lowest temperatures were 12.8¬∞C in Medak and 13.7¬∞C in Adilabad. Other areas saw temps from 15.8¬∞C to 18¬∞C. The highest was 32.5¬∞C in Adilabad and Nizamabad.

articles.title: 'Heavy, intense rainfall' warning for south-east Qld after sweltering heatwave - Australian Broadcasting Corporation
articles.search_term: (heatwave OR "heat wave" OR "severe heatwave" OR "extreme heat" OR "heat spell" OR "scorching heat" OR "blistering heat" OR "sweltering heat" OR "hot winds" OR loo OR "hot loo winds" OR "intense heat" OR "unbearable heat" OR "deadly heat") Andaman and Nicobar Islands
articles.full_text:
In short:
A severe weather warning for heavy, locally intense rainfall in south-east Queensland has been issued by the weather bureau.
It warns the soaking rains could lead to flash flooding in some areas.
What's next?
The heavy rain is due to begin this afternoon and evening and continue through the weekend.
South-east Queensland is being warned to expect "heavy, locally intense rainfall" that will top 150 millimetres in some areas from this afternoon as the region endures scorching hot conditions.
The soaking rains could lead to flash flooding.
The severe weather warning issued at lunchtime covers towns from the Sunshine Coast to the New South Wales border and west beyond Toowoomba.
"Heavy, locally intense rainfall, which may lead to dangerous and life-threatening flash flooding is forecast to develop about the south-east coast from late Thursday evening," it reads.
"Six-hourly rainfall totals between 50mm to 90mm are likely, with isolated higher falls to around 150mm possible."
The warning names the Gold Coast, Toowoomba, Brisbane, Dalby, Kingaroy, Caboolture, Ipswich, Gatton, Cleveland, Cherbourg, Jimboomba and Kilcoy as potentially affected areas.
Parts of Brisbane could cop 150mm
Today, senior forecaster Liam Smart said Brisbane could expect "isolated totals of upwards of 150mm" tomorrow.
"We're talking about some big falls on the forecast for tomorrow," he said.
"We're currently looking for the Brisbane area, a good 25 per cent chance of 120mm of rainfall.
"There could even be isolated totals of 150mm at times.
"And as that pushes into Saturday, the risk does decrease for higher falls, but they're still generally quite high, especially considering we've had a pretty dry January."
The Queensland capital could be drenched by up 210mm from Friday to Sunday if rainfall reaches the higher numbers forecast by the weather bureau.
Minor flooding is possible for some catchments across south-east Queensland, as well as in the Wide Bay and Burnett region.
An initial flood warning has been issued.
Catchments likely to be affected include the Dawson and Don Rivers, Mary River, Upper Brisbane River, Lower Brisbane River and Logan and Albert Rivers.
In western Queensland, minor flood warnings have been issued for the Cooper Creek at Windorah and the Diamantina River at Birdsville.
A severe thunderstorm warning has been issued for areas around Tara in the Darling Downs and Granite Belt, along with north-west of Roma in Warrego and the Central Highlands and Coalfields.
South-east swelters
The promise of rain follows heatwave conditions that have pushed temperatures as high as 9 degrees above average.
Surfers Paradise on the Gold Coast hit 35 degrees Celsius at 1pm, and Boonah in the Scenic Rim reached 37 degrees, three above the forecast maximum.
On the Sunshine Coast, Mooloolaba reached 33C, while on the southern downs, Toowoomba is expected to peak at 34C through the afternoon.
Thunderstorms in the west, low brewing off FNQ coast
Shower and storm activity are also anticipated in the state's west, with decent rainfall expected from the border and Mount Isa through to Longreach and moving east to Charleville and Roma.
This morning, the BOM issued a severe thunderstorm warning for far south-west Queensland, with heavy rainfall expected to affect Ballera, Orientos and Nappa Merrie.
Mr Hayes said the activity was being driven by a significant trough lying through inland parts of the state.
"Pushing into the Channel country, we're starting to see shower and storm activity that will deliver increased activity through the day," he said.
"That will become fairly widespread and deliver potentially severe thunderstorms through parts of the south-east, particularly on Friday."
Meteorologists are keeping a close eye on a tropical low building in the Coral Sea east of Townsville.
The system, 23U, is generating thunderstorm activity offshore that is likely to deliver rainfall over the Cape York vicinity.
Mr Hayes said the low itself remained weak for now.
"It could move closer to the Queensland coast over the weekend, which is potentially when we'll see heavier falls around the Townsville to Mackay area," he said.

articles.title: Family: Arizona man died after hospital discharge in extreme heat despite mental state - AZ Family
articles.search_term: (heatwave OR "heat wave" OR "severe heatwave" OR "extreme heat" OR "heat spell" OR "scorching heat" OR "blistering heat" OR "sweltering heat" OR "hot winds" OR loo OR "hot loo winds" OR "intense heat" OR "unbearable heat" OR "deadly heat") Andaman and Nicobar Islands
articles.full_text:
PHOENIX (AZFamily) ‚Äî A Valley family is suing a Phoenix-area hospital after their son died hours after being discharged alone in triple-digit heat, despite warnings he was too confused to care for himself.
Kaelen Lachica, who had been battling anorexia for nine years, was showing signs of recovery and rebuilding his life when he was admitted to the hospital in August. But within days, his mental state deteriorated dramatically, according to his parents, Seth and Gayle Lachica.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure that he will die if you let him go,‚Äù Seth Lachica told hospital staff, making clear he held medical power of attorney and that his son was confused, hallucinating and unable to make his own medical decisions.
Hours later, just before sunrise, Abrazo Medical Center discharged Kaelen anyway; not to his home address clearly listed in his chart, but alone in an Uber to a downtown Phoenix homeless shelter.
Police body camera video shows what happened next. Kaelen was found lying on a Phoenix sidewalk, his core temperature at 107 degrees. He was pronounced dead hours later.
‚ÄòEverything Changed‚Äô
For years, Seth and Gayle watched their son struggle with anorexia. But in the year leading up to his hospitalization, Kaelen finally appeared to be winning the battle.
‚ÄúHe started to gain weight. He started to do the right things. He started to overcome it,‚Äù Seth said. ‚ÄúAnd his daily routine was driving his golf cart down to the gym.‚Äù
Then came August and the hospital admission. Seth said his son‚Äôs mental state declined rapidly during his stay.
‚ÄúHe just kept saying, ‚Äòburn the books. You get it, dad, burn the books,‚Äô‚Äù Seth recalled, describing his son‚Äôs confused state and hallucinations.
Seth made his concerns explicit to hospital staff, emphasizing his authority as medical power of attorney and his conviction that discharging Kaelen would be life-threatening.
A Desperate Search
Instead of listening to the father‚Äôs warnings, hospital staff discharged Kaelen early in the morning, putting him in an Uber to the shelter rather than allowing him to return home.
‚ÄúThey sent him to Phoenix and dumped him on the sidewalk with an Uber,‚Äù the family said in a statement.
Seth, unaware his son had been discharged, spent hours searching downtown Phoenix. He eventually found Kaelen collapsed on a sidewalk.
‚ÄúI knew, like I could see that he was gone,‚Äù Seth said. ‚ÄúThey were doing CPR and I knew his heart that it had to have been stopped.‚Äù
A Call for Change
The Lachicas‚Äô lawsuit against Abrazo Medical Center centers on what they describe as an inexplicable and preventable tragedy. But their motivation extends beyond seeking accountability.
‚ÄúThis doesn‚Äôt need to happen again. This is just inexcusable,‚Äù Gayle said.
The family is sharing Kaelen‚Äôs story and pursuing legal action in hopes of preventing other families from receiving the same devastating phone call.
‚ÄúI want them to feel embarrassment and regret at what they did,‚Äù Seth said.
When contacted for comment, Abrazo Health did not provide a statement.

articles.title: Masuuliyiin ka Tirsan Dowladda Hoose ee Burco oo Musuqmaasuq Loo Xidhay - hiiraan.com
articles.search_term: (heatwave OR "heat wave" OR "severe heatwave" OR "extreme heat" OR "heat spell" OR "scorching heat" OR "blistering heat" OR "sweltering heat" OR "hot winds" OR loo OR "hot loo winds" OR "intense heat" OR "unbearable heat" OR "deadly heat") Andaman and Nicobar Islands
articles.full_text:
Khamiis, Febraayo 12, 2026 (HOL) - Xafiiska Hantidhawrka Guud ee Somaliland ayaa xabsi dhexe ee magaalada Burco u taxaabay toddoba masuul oo ka tirsan Dawladda Hoose ee Degmada Burco, kuwaas oo lagu eedeeyey lunsi hantiyeed.
Masuuliyiinta la xidhay oo uu magacyadooda baahiyay Xafiiska Hanti Dhawrka Guud ayaa kala ah:
1. Amiin Cabdillaahi Yaasiin ‚Äì Xoghayaha Fulinta Dawladda Hoose Degmada Burco
2. Diiriye Sugaal Rooble ‚Äì Madaxdii Jaangoynta Dhulka. 3. Cabdillaahi Muuse Maxamed ‚Äì Xisaabiyihii Dawladda Hoose Burco. 4. Maxamed Xaaji Muuse Shire ‚Äì Joomitir. 5. Faarax Muuse Siciid ‚Äì Joomitir
6. Cabdicasiis Jaamac Ismaaciil ‚Äì Madaxa Iibka Dawladda Hoose Burco. 7. Maxamed Cali Xirsi ‚Äì Joomitir.
Wararka ayaa sheegaya in dhammaan masuuliyiintan uu Xafiiska Hantidhawrka Guud ku eedeeyey ku lug lahaansho falal la xidhiidha musuqmaasuq iyo lunsi hantiyeed kadib baadhitaanno uu xafiisku sameeyey.
Ilaa hadda ma jiro war rasmi ah oo ka soo baxay masuuliyiinta la xidhay ama qareennadooda oo ku saabsan eedaha loo jeediyey. Sidoo kale, Xafiiska Hantidhawrka Guud si faahfaahsan ugama hadlin xaddiga lacageed ama hantida lagu tuhunsan yahay inay lunsadeen.
Kiiskan ayaa imanaya xilli xafiisku uu kordhiyeen dadaallada lagula dagaallamayo musuqmaasuqa iyo ku takri-falka hantida dadweynaha, iyadoo marar kala duwan la shaaciyey tallaabooyin sharci oo laga qaaday masuuliyiin lagu eedeeyey falal la mid ah.
Dacwadda masuuliyiintan ayaa la filayaa in la horkeeno maxkamadda awoodda u leh, si sharcigu go‚Äôaan uga gaadho eedaha loo haysto.

articles.title: Madaxweyne Deni oo guddoomiye Aadan Madoobe ku eedeeyay inuu Baarlamaanka ka wado howlo ka baxsan shaqadii loo igmaday - hiiraan.com
articles.search_term: (heatwave OR "heat wave" OR "severe heatwave" OR "extreme heat" OR "heat spell" OR "scorching heat" OR "blistering heat" OR "sweltering heat" OR "hot winds" OR loo OR "hot loo winds" OR "intense heat" OR "unbearable heat" OR "deadly heat") Andaman and Nicobar Islands
articles.full_text:
Arbaco, Febraayo 11, 2026 (HOL) - Madaxweynaha Puntland, Siciid Cabdullaahi Deni, ayaa ku eedeeyay Guddoomiyaha Golaha Shacabka, Aadan Madoobe, inuu Baarlamaanka ka dhex wado hawlo ka baxsan shaqadii loo igmaday.
Sidoo kale, wuxuu u mahad celiyay xildhibaannada maalmahan waday kacdoonka ee ka hor yimid wax ka beddelka dastuurka, kuwaas oo uu ku tilmaamay in ay gudanayaan waajibaadkooda dastuuriga ah.
Madaxweyne Deni ayaa ku boorriyay xildhibaanada in ay sii wadaan ilaalinta mas‚Äôuuliyadda loo doortay. Wuxuu sheegay in waxa hadda ka socda Baarlamaanka aysan ahayn shaqadii loo igmaday, isla markaana loo baahan yahay isla xisaabtan dhab ah iyo in si furan looga wada hadlo jihada siyaasadeed ee uu dalku u socdo.
Hadalkaan ayuu madaxweyne Deni ka jeediyay kulan caawa lagu soo dhoweynayay isaga iyo Madaxweynaha Jubbaland, Axmed Madoobe, kaas oo ay soo qaban qaabiyeen Golaha Mustaqbalka Soomaaliya, kana dhacay magaalada Muqdisho.
Deni ayaa sheegay in dalka uu si degdeg ah ugu baahan yahay doorasho loo dhan yahay, isagoo tilmaamay in marxaladda hadda la joogo aysan ku filnayn hadal iyo dood aan miro dhal ahayn.
Wuxuu xusay in loona baahan yahay in la ilaaliyo xeerarka iyo shuruucda lagu heshiiyay.
‚ÄúDalka waxa keliya ee ka dhiman waa in doorasho la qabto; wixii kale waa iska hadal,‚Äù ayuu yiri Deni.
Dhanka kale, Madaxweyne Deni wuxuu caddeeyay inay diyaar u yihiin wada-hadal ay la yeeshaan Madaxweynaha Dowladda Federaalka Soomaaliya.
Deni waxa uu ku celiyay inay ka go‚Äôan tahay ilaalinta midnimada iyo wadajirka dalka, ayna u yimaadeen Muqdisho sidii loo gaari lahaa heshiis dhab ah oo dan u ah ummadda Soomaaliyeed.
